titlestmt.title: VALA/The Four Zoa's : electronic edition
titlestmt.principal: Editors: Morris Eaves, University of Rochester; Robert Essick, University of California, Riverside; and Joseph Viscomi, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
titlestmt.sponsor: The Library of Congress, the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and the University of Rochester

filedesc.editionstmt: Testing new encoding and transcription display for BB209.1

objdescid.origination: William Blake author, inventor, delineator, colorist

objinfo.numberleaves: 73Leaves 10 and 11 (pages 19-20 and 21-22) are two sections of a single leaf bearing a preexisting pencil sketch. Leaves 44 and 45 (pages 87-88 and 89-90) are two sections of Blake's Edward & Elenor engraving; the engraving appears on pages 88 and 89. Leaves 71-73 (pages 141-42, 143-44, and 145-46) are fragments apparently taken from a notebook; the verso of leaf 73 (page 146) is blank.
objinfo.medium: Pen and ink, watercolors, pencil, and charcoal and/or crayonThe rectos of leaves 22-68 and the verso of leaf 69 bear Blake's proof intaglio engravings for Night Thoughts.
objinfo.binding: Pages 1-20 and 23-42 appear to have been bound as a single group at one time, in several stages ; pages 43-84 and 111-12 were bound separately.
objinfo.stabholes: Pages 1-20 and 23-42 have seven holes: approximately 9.1 cm. from the top, 0.24 cm. below the first, approximately 1.1 cm. below the second, approximately 7.5 cm. below the third, approximately 0.8 cm. below the fourth, approximately 7.2 cm. below the fifth, and approximately 5.1 cm. below the sixth. Pages 43-84 and 111-12 have three holes: approximately 15 cm. from the top, approximately 4.15 cm. below the first, and approximately 4.8 cm. below the second.

provenance.name: The British Library
provenance.note: Acquired directly from Blake by John Linnell probably late in Blake's life (i.e., in the 1820s); sold from Linnell's estate, Christie's, 15 March 1918, lot (to "Parsons"); donated anonymously to the British Museum 11 May 1918.

objnote.p: Most if not all of the center-page lines of the text are written over erasures, remnants of which are still visible beneath lines and in the spaces between stanzas. Smudging from erasure of two struck-through lines is visible between lines 17 and 18. E1988 (page 819) gives his recovered text for this page as: "This is the [Dirge] <Song> of [Eno] <Enitharmon> which shook the heavens with wrath / And thus beginneth the book of Vala which Whosoever readeth / If with his Intellect he comprehend the terrible Sentence / The heavens [shall] quake: the earth [shall move] [moves] <was moved> & [shudder] [shudders] <shudderd> & the mountains / With all their woods, the streams & valleys: [wail] <waild> in dismal fear / [To hear] <Hearing> the [Sound] <march> of Long resounding strong heroic verse / Marshalld in order for the day of intellectual battle". M1956 thinks that the third word of the first line might have been "Dream" instead of "Song," though he only professes certainty about a capital "D"; based on Erdman's recovery, he appears to have read the word replaced by "Song" during revision

stage.del: The

l.stage: But Luvah & Vala standing in the bloody sky
l.diplomatic: But Luvah & Vala standing in the bloody sky
l.note: Lines 6-7 and 13-24, comprising the middle section of the central text (excluding the marginal addition as transcribed here) appears to have been circled in pencil at one point, but then the circle was erased; lines 22-24 may have been circled separately. In addition, there are remnants of thick pencil lines under each of the lines of text that are likely erased guiding lines, though they appear to be much blunter and thicker in comparison to other guiding lines in the manuscript-or even the remnant of the vertical line beside "They" and "With" in lines 4 and 5 respectively; thus, the lines of text may have been struck through in pencil, all of which were also later erased. "But" is written over erasures, a portion of which ("The shades(?) of(?)" B1963f, B1978; "The ?shades of" E1988) is still visible to the left.

l.stage: On high remaind alone forsaken in fierce jealousy
l.diplomatic: On high remaind alone forsaken in fierce jealousy

l.stage: TheBut purple nighttheand crimson morning & the golden day descending
l.diplomatic: TheBut purple nighttheand crimson morning & the golden day descending
l.note: "But" and "and" are written over erased "The" and "the" respectively. Between "morning" and "golden," the remnant of an erased "the" is still quite legible.

There appear to be more erased pencil lines just below and extending far into the right margin, beneath and right of the marginal addition. E1988 records this text as "orbits high" and then "demons by the thousands out of a golden cloud xxxx xxx".

l.diplomatic: In clouds of sweet obscurity my beauteous form dissolving

l.stage: Ho But if among the virgins
wl thou over the body of death tis thine
l.diplomatic: Howl thou over the body of death tis thine But if among the virgins

l.stage: Of summer I have seen thee sleep & turn thy cheek delighted
l.diplomatic: Of summer I have seen thee sleep & turn thy cheek delighted

l.stage: Upon the rose or lilly pale .or on a bank where sleeps
l.diplomatic: Upon the rose or lillylily pale .or on a bank where sleeps

l.stage: The beamy daughters of the light starting they rise they flee
l.diplomatic: The beamy daughters of the light starting they rise they flee

l.stage: From thy fierce love for tho II am disolvd in the bright God
l.diplomatic: From thy fierce love for thothough II am disolvd in the bright God

l.stage: My spirit still pursues thy false love over rocks & valleys
l.diplomatic: My spirit still pursues thy false love over rocks & valleys

l.stage: Los answerd therefore fade I thus dissolvd in rapturd trance
l.diplomatic: Los answerdanswered therefore fade I thus dissolvd in rapturdraptured trance

l.stage: Thou canst repose on clouds of secrecy while oer my limbs
l.diplomatic: Thou canst repose on clouds of secrecy while oerover my limbs

l.stage: Cold dews & hoary frost creeps tho I lie on banks of summer
l.diplomatic: Cold dews & hoary frost creeps thothough I lie on banks of summer

l.stage: Among the beauties of the World Cold & repining Los
l.diplomatic: Among the beauties of the World Cold & repining Los

l.stage: Still dies for Enitharmon nor a spirit springs from my dead corse
l.diplomatic: Still dies for Enitharmon nor a spirit springs from my dead corsecorpse

l.stage: Then I am dead till thou revivest me with thy sweet song
l.diplomatic: Then I am dead till thou revivest me with thy sweet song

l.stage: Now taking on Ahanias form & now the form of Enion
l.diplomatic: Now taking on Ahanias form & now the form of Enion

l.stage: I know thee not as once I knew thee in those blessed fields
l.diplomatic: I know thee not as once I knew thee in those blessed fields

l.stage: Where memory wishes to repose among the flocks of Tharmas
l.diplomatic: Where memory wishes to repose among the flocks of Tharmas

l.stage: Enitharmon answerd Wherefore didst thou throw thine arms around
l.diplomatic: Enitharmon answerdanswered Wherefore didst thou throw thine arms around

l.stage: Ahanias Image I decievd thee & will still decieve
l.diplomatic: Ahanias Image I decievddeceived thee & will still decievedeceive

l.stage: Urizen saw thy sin & hid his beams in darkning Clouds
l.diplomatic: Urizen saw thy sin & hid his beams in darkningdarkening Clouds

l.stage: I still keep watch altho I tremble & wither across the heavens
l.diplomatic: I still keep watch althoalthough I tremble & wither across the heavens

l.stage: In strong vibrations of fierce jealousy for thou art mine
l.diplomatic: In strong vibrations of fierce jealousy for thou art mine

l.stage: Created for my willmyslave tho strong tho I am weak
l.diplomatic: Created for my willmyslave thothough strong thothough I am weak

l.stage: Farewell the God calls me away I depart in my sweet bliss
l.diplomatic: Farewell the God calls me away I depart in my sweet bliss

l.stage: She fled vanishing on the wind
And left a dead cold corse
l.diplomatic: She fled vanishing on the wind And left a dead cold corsecorpse

l.stage: In Los's arms howlings began over the body of death
l.diplomatic: In Los's arms howlings began over the body of death

l.stage: Los spoke . Thy God in vain shall call thee if by my strong power
l.diplomatic: Los spoke . Thy God in vain shall call thee if by my strong power

l.stage: I can infuse my dear revenge into his glowing braeeast
l.diplomatic: I can infuse my dear revenge into his glowing braeeast

l.stage: Then jealousy shall shadow all his mountains & Ahania
l.diplomatic: Then jealousy shall shadow all his mountains & Ahania

l.stage: Curse thee thou plague of woful Los & seek revenge on thee
l.diplomatic: Curse thee thou plague of wofulwoeful Los & seek revenge on thee

l.stage: So saying in deep sobs he languishd till dead he also fell
l.diplomatic: So saying in deep sobs he languishdlanguished till dead he also fell

l.stage: Night passd & Enitharmon eer the dawn returnd in bliss
l.diplomatic: Night passd & Enitharmon eerere the dawn returndreturned in bliss

l.stage: reviving him to Life his groans were terrible
l.diplomatic: reviving him to Life his groans were terrible

l.stage: She sang Oer Los . I sieze the sphery harp I strike the strings
l.diplomatic: She sang Oerover Los . I siezeseize the sphery harp I strike the strings

l.stage: But thus she sang
l.diplomatic: But thus she sang

l.stage: At the first Sound the Golden sun arises from the deep
l.diplomatic: At the first Sound the Golden sun arises from the deep

l.stage: And shakes his awful hair
l.diplomatic: And shakes his awful hair

l.stage: The Eccho wakes the moon to unbind her silver locks
l.diplomatic: The Ecchoecho wakes the moon to unbind her silver locks

l.stage: The golden sun bears on my song
l.diplomatic: The golden sun bears on my song

l.stage: And nine bright spheres of harmony rise round the fiery king
l.diplomatic: And nine bright spheres of harmony rise round the fiery king

l.stage: Saying, Go & die the Death of Man for Vala the sweet wanderer
l.diplomatic: Saying, Go & die the Death of Man for Vala the sweet wanderer
l.note: According to E1988, lines 1-10 (as transcribed here) are written over erased text. However, only specific portions appear to have been written over erasures; the handwriting appears to be somewhat different than that of "Luvah & Vala" in line 10 and following, though "I saw that" just before is clearly an overwrite.

l.stage: I will turn the volutions of your Ears outward; & bend your Nostrils
l.diplomatic: I will turn the volutions of your Ears outward; & bend your Nostrils
l.note: There is a smudge under "I will turn", though the words do not appear to have been written over an erasure.

l.stage: Downward; & your fluxile Eyes englob'd, roll round in fear
l.diplomatic: Downward; & your fluxile Eyes englob'englobedd, roll round in fear
l.note: There is a smudge under "fluxile", though it does not appear to have been written over an erasure.

l.stage: Your withring Lips & Tongue shrink up into a narrow circle
l.diplomatic: Your withringwithering Lips & Tongue shrink up into a narrow circle
l.note: There is a smudge under the end of s"hrink" and "up", though the words do not appear to have been written over an erasure.

l.stage: Till into narrow forms you creep. Go take your fiery way
l.diplomatic: Till into narrow forms you creep. Go take your fiery way

l.stage: And learn what 'tis to absorb the Man you Spirits of Pity & Love
l.diplomatic: And learn what 'tis to absorb the Man you Spirits of Pity & Love

l.stage: O Urizen why are thou pale at the visions of Ahania
l.diplomatic: O Urizen why are thou pale at the visions of Ahania
l.note: Lines 7-8 are written over erased pencil text originally in this stanza break and continuing into the right margin as two more separate lines. Portions of the marginal text are still visible and appear to be similar to the ink text; according to E1988, the pencil lines were indeed identical to those in ink, while B1963f believes that they "may have been identical".

l.stage: Listen to her who loves thee lest we also are driven away.
l.diplomatic: Listen to her who loves thee lest we also are driven away.

l.stage: They heard the voice & fled swift as the winters setting sun
l.diplomatic: They heard the voice & fled swift as the winterswinter's setting sun

l.stage: And now the Human Blood foamd high , I saw that Luvah & Vala
l.diplomatic: And now the Human Blood foamdfoamed high , I saw that Luvah & Vala
l.note: Above "I saw that" in line 12, there are remnants of erased pencil text ("I saw[?] that" B1963f, B1978; "I saw that" E1988).
"I saw that" is written over an erasure ("the Spirits" E1988).

l.stage: Went down the Human Heart where Paradise & its joys abounded.
l.diplomatic: Went down the Human Heart where Paradise & its joys abounded.

l.stage: In jealous fears in fury & rage, & flames roll'd round their fervid feet
l.diplomatic: In jealous fears in fury & rage, & flames roll'drolled round their fervid feet
l.note: There may be an erased pencil word above the space between "&" and "flames"--or it could just be a random smudge.

l.stage: And the vast form of Nature like a Serpent play'd before them
l.diplomatic: And the vast form of Nature like a Serpent play'dplayed before them

l.stage: And as they went in folding fires & thunders of the deep
l.diplomatic: And as they went in folding fires & thunders of the deep

l.stage: Vala shrunk in like the dark sea that leaves its slimy banks
l.diplomatic: Vala shrunk in like the dark sea that leaves its slimy banks

l.stage: And from her bosom Luvah fell far as the east & west
l.diplomatic: And from her bosom Luvah fell far as the east & west

l.stage: And the vast form of Nature like a Serpent roll'd between.
l.diplomatic: And the vast form of Nature like a Serpent roll'drolled between.

stage.handShift: Whether this is Jerusalem or Babylon we know not

diplomatic.handShift: Whether this is Jerusalem or Babylon we know not

l.note: Lines 24-25 are added in pencil in a stanza break beginning just beneath line 23 and continuing vertically, text rotated counter-clockwise, up into the right margin starting with "All is Confusion". They are written over several erased lines in this space that also continue up the right margin below line 25 (as transcribed here). E1988 gives this erased text as "?Thenlabour endedlove for Vala / Our hearts sickweon his Rock / We fled from ?Jerusalem ?after ?the Merciful Lord & Saviour.

l.stage: She ended. for his wrathful throne burst forth the black hail storm
l.diplomatic: She ended. for his wrathful throne burst forth the black hail storm
l.note: There is an erased word still visible below "hail storm" in line 26 ("Leaping <?>" B1963f).

l.stage: Am I not God said Urizen. Who is Equal to me
l.diplomatic: Am I not God said Urizen. Who is Equal to me
l.note: Lines 28-30 are written over two erased pencil lines, which appear to be similar or identical to lines 28-29 (according to B1963f the erased lines were indeed identical to lines 28-29); line 30 was clearly added after lines 28-29, over the second erased pencil line.

l.stage: Do I not stretch the heavens abroad or fold them up like a garment
l.diplomatic: Do I not stretch the heavens abroad or fold them up like a garment

l.stage: He spoke mustering his heavy clouds around him black opake
l.diplomatic: He spoke mustering his heavy clouds around him black opakeopaque

l.stage: Albion closd the Western Gate &
l.diplomatic: Albion closdclosed the Western Gate &
l.note: The marginal addition transcribed here in lines 13, 15-16, 17, and 19 is written in the left margin directly opposite the center-page text.

l.stage: cshut America out by the Atlantic
l.diplomatic: cshut America out by the Atlantic
l.note: The "s" of "shut" possibly may have been written over "c" or rewritten.

l.stage: for a Curse and hidden horror
l.diplomatic: for a Curse and hidden horror

l.stage: and an altar of victims to Sin
l.diplomatic: and an altar of victims to Sin

l.stage: & Repentance
l.diplomatic: & Repentance

stage.handShift: All is Confusion All is tumult & we alone are escaped

diplomatic.handShift: All is Confusion All is tumult & we alone are escaped
